Do you rely on the Dharma or on the self?
If so, what is the problem?
Both have faults.
Why is it so?
If you rely on the Dharma, the Dharma has no function.
In all dharmas without function,
how do you establish the internal and external bases?
If you rely on the self, the true nature of the self does not exist.
How do you establish the internal and external bases based on the self?
Answer: They are established only based on the Dharma, but not all of them.
Namely, the six consciousnesses are the basis for defiled and pure dharmas.
If something serves as the basis for the six consciousnesses, it is called an internal base.
If it serves as the object, it is called an external base.
Therefore, the names of the internal and external bases are established based on the Dharma.
Furthermore, if a dharma is a faculty, it is established as an internal base.
If a dharma is the meaning of a faculty, it is established as an external base.
Moreover, if a dharma is the subject, it is established as an internal sense base.
If a dharma is the object, it is established as an external sense base.
Some say:
The internal and external sense bases are established based on the self.
The self is precisely the mind.
Because it is the basis of the grasping of self.
The name self is provisionally established on this mind.
As a sutra says:
By well subduing the self, the wise one attains rebirth in the heavens
One should well subdue the mind, for a well-subdued mind leads to happiness
Since one well subdues the mind, one well subdues the self.
Therefore, one should know that the name self is provisionally established on the mind.ğŸ”½The basis of this self is established as an internal sense base.
That which is the object of the self is established as an external sense base.
However, the names internal and external are not fully accomplished.ğŸ”½That which is internal to the self is called external to another.
That which is external to the self is called internal to another.
Therefore, the names internal and external are established based on one, and are not indeterminate.

Like a disease, like a boil, like an arrow, and a source of affliction.

Why is this?
Because there is a self, there is what belongs to the self.
Because there is the view of self, there is the view of what belongs to the self.
Because there are five views of self, there are fifteen views of what belongs to the self.
Because there is self-grasping, there is grasping what belongs to the self.

Moreover, the World-Honored One wanted his disciples to first cultivate mindfulness of the internal dharmas.
That is to say, practitioners first cultivate mindfulness in relation to internal dharmas.
Having perfected it, they then extend it to the external.
Due to these various causes and conditions,
therefore the World-Honored One only exhorts one to know the internal.
As a sutra says, there are six internal sense bases.
A sutra also says there are six contact bases.
Question: What is the difference between these two sets of six?
Some say:
These two are no different.
Why is it so?
The six internal sense bases are the six contact bases.
The six contact bases are the six internal sense bases.
Although the terms differ, the meaning is no different.
Some also say:
There are also differences.
That is to say, the difference in names is called the six internal sense bases and the six contact bases.
Moreover, those of the same class are called the six contact bases.
Those of the same class but different are called the six internal sense bases.
Furthermore, dharmas that can arise are called the six bases of contact.
Dharmas that cannot arise are called the six internal bases.
Furthermore, those with function are called the six bases of contact.
Those without function are called the six internal bases.
If it is said like this,
The present ones are called the six bases of contact.
The past and future ones are called the six internal bases.
Furthermore, those that have already arisen are called the six bases of contact.
Those that have not yet arisen are called the six internal bases.
If it is said like this,
The past and present are called the six bases of contact.
The future is called the six internal bases.
Furthermore, those that are the correct support of mind and mental factors are called the six bases of contact.
Mind and mental factors that are not the correct support,
Only revolving in emptiness, are called the six internal bases.
Furthermore, the six bases such as the eye serve as the basis for contact, so they are called the six bases of contact.
They serve as the basis for other mind and mental factors, so they are called the six internal bases.
The Venerable PÄrÅ›va said:

If there is something that is done, it is called the six bases of contact.
Like a monk's bowl.
If speaking of its intrinsic nature, it is simply called a bowl.
When a monk uses it, it is called the monk's bowl.
The Venerable VaibhÄá¹£ika says:

If it serves as the basis for contact, it is called the six bases of contact.
Like an iron ghee bowl.
If speaking of its intrinsic nature, it is simply called an iron bowl.
When it contains ghee, it is called an iron ghee bowl.
Question: The six sense bases such as the eye are also the basis for feeling, etc.
Why are they only called the bases of contact and not the bases of feeling, etc.?
Answer: They should also be called the bases of feeling, etc., but it is not said.
One should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Moreover, the sÅ«tra takes the superior to include the inferior.
That is to say, among all minds and mental factors,
contact is the most superior.
If the base of touch is mentioned, you should understand that the bases of feeling, etc., are also implied.
Next, mind and mental activities take contact as their life.
They are sustained by contact and are attracted by contact.
Because of the power of contact, they are able to appear.
Therefore, it is called the base of touch.
That is, mind and mental activities flow and scatter over objects.
Contact holds them and causes them to unite.
Also, if there were no contact, all minds and mental activities would be like dead bodies and would be unable to touch and oppose their objects.
All have the function of touching objects because of the power of contact.
Just as the body is able to feel touch because it has the vital power.
Therefore, the eyes, etc., are only called the base of touch.
As a scripture says,
The six internal sense bases are called this shore, and the six external sense bases are called the other shore.
Question: What similarity do the six internal and external sense bases have with this shore and the other shore
that they are spoken of in this way?
Answer: They act as the support and objects of mind and mental activities.
There is near and far, resembling this shore and the other shore, and for that reason they are spoken of in this way.
It is like the two shores of a river.
The near is called this shore, and the distant is called the other shore.
In this way, the six sense bases are the support for mind and mental factors.
As the support, they are near, like this shore.
As the object, they are distant, like the other shore.
Moreover, it is said that mind and mental factors first enter and cross over this shore and the other shore.
Just as for sentient beings,
the place where they first enter the river is called this shore.
The place where they have already crossed the river is called the other shore.
In this way, that which is the support for mind and mental factors
is like the first entry, so it is called this shore.
That which is the object is like having already crossed over, so it is called the other shore.
Therefore, the internal and external sense bases are called this shore and the other shore.
Moreover, a sutra says:ğŸ”½Nirvana, which is quiescent extinction, is called the other shore.
Nirvana is only categorized as an external sense base. Since it is called the other shore,
the six internal sense bases are given the name this shore.
As a sutra says:ğŸ”½The aggregates are this shore.
The extinction of the aggregates is the other shore.
The aggregates are precisely birth and death.
Among the aggregates, the six internal sense bases are supreme,ğŸ”½therefore the six internal sense bases are called this shore.
Since the six internal sense bases are called this shore,
the six external sense bases are called the other shore.
Question: What dharma in this [teaching] is like a river,
and is the six internal and external sense bases spoken of as this shore and the other shore?
Answer: The mind and mental factors are like a river,
therefore the internal and external sense bases are this shore and the other shore.
Just as a rushing river carries this shore and the other shore,
sentient and insentient beings alike head for the great ocean.
The mind and mental factors are also like this.
They carry the sentient beings included in the internal and external sense bases,
heading together for the great ocean of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Question: Who is the boat and raft in this river?
Answer: The eightfold noble path is like a boat and raft,
relied upon by hundreds of thousands of beings.
They cross from this shore of the river to the other shore and roam as they please.
In this way, innumerable and boundless sentient beings rely on the noble path.
From the shore of birth and death to the other shore of nirvana.
Freely enjoying themselves.
The eightfold noble path is like a boat or raft.
As the sutra says:
There are eight kinds of mastery and ten kinds of universal bases.
Question: Since those eight and ten are also called bases,
why are there only twelve bases?
Answer: Those eight and ten are all included in these twelve bases.
Because their intrinsic nature, co-existence, and association are included in the mind base and dharma base.
As the sutra says:
There are four formless bases.
Namely, the base of infinite space, the base of infinite consciousness, the base of nothingness, and the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One speak of the four formless [absorptions] using the term base?
Answer: In order to destroy the non-Buddhists' attachment to liberation.
That is to say, the non-Buddhists take the four formless [absorptions] to be the four nirvanas.
One takes the base of infinite space to be the nirvana of no body.
The second is to take the sphere of infinite consciousness as the nirvana of infinite mind.
The third is to take the sphere of nothingness as the nirvana of pure aggregates.
The fourth is to take the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as the nirvana of the worldly stupa.
In order to refute such heterodox attachments to nirvana,
it is said that the four formless [absorptions] are called places of rebirth, not true liberation.
True liberation is called nirvana.
As a sutra says:
There are also two places.
One is the place of beings with no thought,
and the other is the place of neither perception nor non-perception.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One speak of these two places?
Answer: In order to destroy the notion of liberation of non-Buddhists.
That is to say, non-Buddhists give rise to the notion of liberation in these two places.
In order to destroy that notion, the Buddha said that these two are called places of rebirth, not true liberation.
Furthermore, in order to destroy the notion of non-return of non-Buddhists.
That is to say, non-Buddhists give rise to the notion of non-return in these two places.
The Buddha spoke of these two places as places of regression and return in order to destroy this idea.
It means that after dying in those places, one regresses and returns to the various realms, destinies, and births.
One transmigrates in birth and death without respite.
Moreover, in order to destroy the non-dispersal idea of non-Buddhists.
Non-Buddhists hold that these two places are true liberation and will never disperse and be destroyed.
In order to destroy this attachment, the Buddha said that these two are places of dispersal.
It means that after dying from there, one disperses and falls towards the various realms, destinies, and births.
One transmigrates in birth and death without respite.
If one dies from the heaven of non-conceptual beings, one will definitely disperse and fall to be reborn in the desire realm.
If one dies from the neither perception nor non-perception [heaven],
non-sages will disperse and fall to be reborn in lower realms.
Moreover, observing that the lifespan in these two places is long,
non-Buddhists hold it to be liberation.
Only the places where ordinary beings are reborn have long lifespans.
There is none that surpasses the non-conceptual heaven.
It is said that their lifespan is five hundred great eons.
All sentient beings are born in this place.
The lifespan is long and far-reaching, surpassing the place of neither perception nor non-perception.
That is to say, their lifespan is eighty thousand great eons.
In order to dispel the non-Buddhists' attachment to this as liberation, the Buddha called these two places places of birth and not true liberation.
Furthermore, the Buddha spoke of these two places elsewhere by two other names.
One is called abode of sentient beings,
and the other is called abode of consciousness.
In these two places, he also spoke of them by two other names.
One is called abode of sentient beings,
and the other is called place.
Therefore, in these two, he spoke of them using the term place.
That is to say, the place of rebirth.
Furthermore, the Buddha said that the abodes of consciousness are the abodes of sentient beings.
There are abodes of sentient beings that are not abodes of consciousness.
These two places are not without this, so he spoke of them using the term place.
This is the meaning of the place where sentient beings dwell.

The five aggregates are the form aggregate, feeling aggregate, perception aggregate, formation aggregate, and consciousness aggregate.
Why is this treatise composed?
The answer is: in order to extensively analyze the meaning of the sutras.
Namely, in the sutras it is said:
There are five aggregates, form up to consciousness.
Although this is said, it is not extensively explained.
The sutras are the basis of this treatise.
What is not explained there is now wished to be explained, so this treatise is composed.
What is the form aggregate?
The answer is: as explained in the sutras:
All forms are the four great elements and what is derived from the four great elements.
Other sutras also say:
What is the form aggregate?
All forms, whether past, future, or present,
whether internal or external, gross or subtle,
inferior or superior, far or near.
All of this is briefly gathered into one aggregate and called the form aggregate.
The same is said in detail for the consciousness aggregate.
The Abhidharma says:
What is the form aggregate?
It is the ten form sense bases and the form included in the sense base of mental objects. This is called the form aggregate.
Question: What is the difference in meaning of these three passages?
Answer: Each refutes what is said by other schools.
Question: As a sutra says:ğŸ”½All forms
are the four great elements and what is derived from the four great elements.
What is this refuting?
Answer: This refutes what KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra and others say.
That is, the Buddha observes in the future there will be KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra and others who will say:
Outside of the four great elements there is no separate derivative.
In order to refute this view, it is said:
All forms are the four great elements and the four great elements that are derivative.
It shows that there are derivative forms apart from the great elements.
Question: Another sutra also says:
All forms, whether past, future, or present,
and so on, explaining in detail.
What is this refuting?
Answer: This refutes what is said by non-Buddhists.
Namely, there was a non-Buddhist renunciant named Staff-Topknot during the Buddha's lifetime.
He denied the existence of past and future.
In order to refute this view, the World-Honored One said: All forms, whether past, future, or present,
and so on, explaining in detail.
It shows that there are past and future forms and so on.
Question: The Abhidharma says:
What is the form aggregate? It refers to the ten form sense bases and the form included in the sense base of mental objects.
What is this refuting?
Answer: This refutes what is said by the Analogists.
Because the proponents of similes deny that there is a place where form is not included.
This Venerable DharmatrÄta also says:
All forms are the basis and objects of the five sense consciousnesses.
How can form be neither the basis nor object of the five sense consciousnesses?
In order to refute this view, this is said.
What is the form aggregate?
It is the ten form sense bases and the form included in the sense base of mental objects.
If the forms included in the sense base of mental objects really exist,
how can we understand what the Venerable DharmatrÄta said?
Answer: It is not necessary to understand it, because it is not part of the Tripiá¹­aka.
If it must be understood, it should be corrected to his statement:
All forms are the basis of the five consciousnesses,
and the objects of the six consciousnesses. The forms included in the sense base of mental objects,
although not the basis or objects of the five consciousnesses,
are included in the form that is the object of mental consciousness.
Moreover, the forms included in the sense base of mental objects arise in dependence on the four great elements.
Therefore, in terms of their basis, they are said to be included among the objects of the body consciousness.
Therefore, the Venerable One's explanation is also correct.
Question: What is the aggregate of feeling?
Answer: It is the six groups of feeling.
Namely, feeling born from eye contact,
up to feeling born from mind contact.
Both the sutras and Abhidharma all explain it like this.
Question: What is the aggregate of perception?
Answer: It is the six groups of perception. Namely, perception born from eye contact,
up to perception born from mind contact.
Both the sutras and Abhidharma all explain it like this.
Question: What is the aggregate of mental formations?
Answer: The sutras say it is the six groups of intention.
Namely, intention born from eye contact,
up to intention born from mind contact.
The Abhidharma explains that this aggregate of mental formations
is broadly of two kinds.
Namely, associated mental formations and dissociated mental formations.
And so on, explaining in detail.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One, among the associated and dissociated mental formations,
specifically explain intention as the aggregate of mental formations, and not the other mental formations?
Answer: Intention is the foremost in the aggregate of mental activities.
Because intention can guide and nurture all activities, the Buddha speaks of it in particular.
Just as craving is the foremost in the aggregate of causes of suffering,
Because craving can guide and nurture all causes of suffering, the Buddha speaks of it in particular.
Moreover, it is called activity because it creates conditioned phenomena.
Intention is of the nature of creation, other dharmas are not like this.
Therefore the Buddha speaks of intention in particular as the aggregate of activity.
Question: What is the aggregate of consciousness?
Answer: The six groups of consciousness.
That is, eye consciousness up to mind consciousness.
Both the sutras and the Abhidharma all say this.
This is called the intrinsic nature, substance, essence, aspect, and original nature of the aggregates.
The intrinsic nature has been explained.
The reason will now be explained.
Question: Why is it called an aggregate? What is the meaning of aggregate?
Answer: The meaning of accumulation is the meaning of aggregate.ğŸ”½The meaning of combination is the meaning of aggregate.ğŸ”½The meaning of heap is the meaning of aggregate.
The meaning of brief is the meaning of aggregate.
If it is a worldly designation, it is the same as the designation of the aggregates.
If it is a term for many, it is a term for the aggregates.
The meaning of accumulation is the meaning of the aggregates.
It means all that exists in form.
Whether past, future, or present.
Explained in detail up to far or near.
In this way, all are collectively called one accumulation and established as the form aggregate.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, the meaning of accumulation is also like this.
The meaning of combination is the meaning of the aggregates.
It means all that exists in form.
Whether past, future, or present.
Explained in detail up to far or near.
In this way, all are collectively called one combination and established as the form aggregate.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, the meaning of combination is also like this.
The meaning of accumulation is the meaning of the aggregates.
It is like various things collectively called one accumulation, named the aggregate of miscellaneous things.
In this way, all forms are collectively called one accumulation and established as the form aggregate.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, the meaning of accumulation is also like this.
The meaning of summary is the meaning of the aggregates.
It means all forms,
whether past, future, or present,
and so on up to whether far or near.
All of this is generally summarized and established as the form aggregate.
The concise meaning of the consciousness aggregate is also like this.
Question: Can past, future, and present forms be summarized and aggregated?
Answer: Although their substance cannot be summarized and aggregated,
their names can be summarized and aggregated.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, one should understand it is also like this.
Question: If so, the unconditioned should also be established as an aggregate,
because the names of the unconditioned can be summarized and aggregated.
Answer: Because conditioned dharmas have function, they have the meaning of being summarized and aggregated.
Although their substance cannot be summarized and aggregated at times,
they summarize and aggregate their names to establish the form and other aggregates.
Because unconditioned dharmas have no function, they have no meaning of being summarized and aggregated.
Although their names can be summarized and aggregated,
they cannot be established as aggregates.
If the world establishes, it is the establishment of the aggregates.
It means that the form aggregate can be established as having three time periods.
Up to the consciousness aggregate can also be established as having three time periods.
If multiple terms are the same as the aggregates,
like many possessions are called the aggregate of possessions.ğŸ”½Many grains are called the aggregate of grains.
Many troops are called the aggregate of troops.
Although many people do not overlap their shoulders,
they are called an army because they have the same purpose.
In the same way, although the colors of many koá¹­is, nayutas, and so forth of subtle atoms
are far apart, they are combined and established as the form aggregate because they have the same characteristics.
Up to the consciousness aggregate, although its innumerable moments are far apart,
they are combined and established as the consciousness aggregate because they have the same characteristics.
Question: If multiple terms are the same as the aggregates,
is there a single subtle atom called the form aggregate?
There is an explanation:
A single subtle atom cannot be established as the form aggregate.
If establishing the form aggregate, many subtle atoms are required.
There is also an explanation:
Because each subtle atom has the characteristics of an aggregate.
It can also be established separately as a form aggregate.
If a single atom has no characteristics of the form aggregate,
many accumulations should also not be aggregates. The masters of the Abhidharma say:
If one observes the provisional aggregates, one should say:
A single atom is a part of one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate.
If one does not observe the provisional aggregates, one should say:
A single atom is one realm, one sense base, and one aggregate.
It is like a person who takes a grain from a heap of grain.
Another person asks, What do you take?
If that person observes the heap of grain, they should answer:
I take a grain from the heap of grain.
If they do not observe the heap of grain, they should answer:
I am now gathering grain.
Up to the momentary consciousness aggregate, the question and answer are also like this.
Thus the general names of the aggregates have been explained.
Now we should distinguish the sequence of the aggregates.
Question: Why did the World-Honored One first speak of the form aggregate?
Up to the last, does it speak of the consciousness aggregate?
Answer: Because it accords with the sequence of the text and the characteristics it expresses.
Moreover, because it accords with the sequence of the Dharma that is spoken, received, and upheld.
Moreover, because it accords with the sequence of the Dharma in terms of gross and subtle.
That is to say, among the five aggregates, the form aggregate is the grossest, so the Buddha speaks of it first.
Among the four aggregates, the feeling aggregate is the grossest, so it is spoken of next after form.
Question: The four aggregates such as feeling have no location and no form, so
how can it be said that they are gross or subtle?
Answer: Although they have no location and no form,
they establish the names gross and subtle based on their modes of activity.
It is like the worldly saying,
My hands and feet hurt.ğŸ”½My head and belly hurt.
My limbs and joints hurt.
Pain is precisely feeling.
Because feeling can be established like form,
it is said that feeling is the grossest among the formless aggregates.
Among the three aggregates, conception is the grossest,
because conceptions such as male and female are easily understood, so it is spoken of next after feeling.
Among the two aggregates, the aggregate of karmic activities is the coarsest in characteristics.
Because the characteristics of craving, hatred, and delusion, etc., are easily understood, it is explained after perception.
The aggregate of consciousness is the most subtle, generally grasping the characteristics of objects and being difficult to understand, so it is explained last.

Furthermore, from beginningless time, men and women have loved each other's forms, so form is explained first.ğŸ”½Loving each other's forms is due to craving the taste of feelings, so feelings are explained next.
This craving for the taste of feelings is due to inverted perceptions, so perceptions are explained next.
These inverted perceptions arise from afflictions, so karmic activities are explained next.
All afflictions arise based on consciousness, and the various consciousnesses are defiled, so consciousness is explained last.
Furthermore, two kinds of form contemplation are the gateway to the nectar of entering the Buddha's teachings,
namely, the contemplation of impurity and the mindfulness of breathing.
Therefore, form is explained first.
Having contemplated form, one can see the faults of feelings, so feelings are explained next. Having seen the faults of feelings, perceptions are not inverted, so perceptions are explained next.
When perceptions are non-inverted, afflictions do not arise, so karmic activities are explained next.
Because it is free from afflictions, consciousness is then purified. Therefore, consciousness is explained last.
Furthermore, the form aggregate is like a vessel.
It is the basis and object of the formless aggregates.
Therefore, it is explained first.
Feeling is like food and drink, which are the main objects of craving. Therefore, feeling is explained next.
Conceptualization is like a seasoning. Due to inverted conceptualization, one becomes attached to feelings. Therefore, conceptualization is explained next.
Dispositional forces are like cooks. Afflictions and karma are able to create and produce. Therefore, dispositional forces are explained next.
Consciousness is like the eater. It is able to cognize objects. Therefore, consciousness is explained last.
Furthermore, the five are explained in this order based on realms and stages.
In the desire realm, various wonderful desires have the appearance of form. Therefore, form is explained first.
In the meditative absorptions, feelings such as joy and pleasure are manifest. Therefore, feeling is explained next.
In the first three formless states, the grasping of emptiness, etc., has the appearance of conceptualization. Therefore, conceptualization is explained next.
In the stage of the peak of existence, thought is supreme. The appearance of dispositional forces is manifest. Therefore, dispositional forces are explained next.
Form, etc., are the four kinds of abodes of consciousness.
Consciousness is the basis, so it is mentioned last. Question: The five aggregates are conditioned, so they should all be called formations.
Why is only one called formation?
Answer: Although the eighteen elements are all dharmas,
only one is called the dharma element.
Extending this, although the Three Jewels and the Three Refuges are all dharmas, only one is called the Dharma Jewel and the Dharma Refuge.
In the same way, although the five aggregates are all formations,ğŸ”½only one is called the formation aggregate, without any fault.
Moreover, the formation aggregate has one name,
while the other aggregates have two names.
The one name is
the common name.
This is because the five aggregates are all formations.
The two names are the common and uncommon names.
The common name is as mentioned above.
The uncommon name is
the other four aggregates. In order to make it easier to understand, the uncommon names are shown.
The formation aggregate has no uncommon name,
so only the common name is shown, thus it is called the formation aggregate.
Furthermore, the characteristic of birth of all conditioned forces is included only in this aggregate, and therefore it is called the aggregate of formations.
Furthermore, the four characteristics of conditioned forces are the seal and banner of all conditioned forces.
They distinguish conditioned forces from unconditioned forces.
Those characteristics are included only in this aggregate, and therefore it is called the aggregate of formations.
Furthermore, the classes of names, phrases, and syllables express, reveal, and display the nature, characteristics, and functions of conditioned forces, making them easy to understand.
Those three are included only in this aggregate, and therefore it is called the aggregate of formations.
Furthermore, the gate of liberation of emptiness, which realizes that all conditioned forces are empty and non-self,
is included in this aggregate, and therefore it is called the aggregate of formations.
Question: The view of a real self grasps conditioned forces as the self and what belongs to the self.
That view is also included in this aggregate.
How is it that this aggregate is not called the aggregate of self?
Answer: The view of a real self is a false grasping.
It does not accord with the true characteristics of conditioned forces.
Therefore, this aggregate is not established as the name of self.
The gate of liberation of emptiness realizes the true characteristics of conditioned forces.
Therefore, this aggregate is named formation based on them.
Next, discriminating the specific and common characteristics of formations,
establishing the specific and common characteristics of formations,
destroying the ignorance of self-nature and the ignorance of objects,
neither increasing nor decreasing in all formations,
the wisdom that understands reality is included only in this aggregate, therefore it is named the formation aggregate.
The other aggregates are not like this, so they are given separate names.
Next, because it includes many formations, it is named the formation aggregate.
As for including many formations, it means that within this aggregate there are formations that are associated and not associated,
those that have a basis and those that do not,ğŸ”½those that have objects and those that do not,
those that have aspects and those that do not,
those that are alert and those that are not.
The other aggregates are not like this, so they are given separate names.
Next, formation means creation.
Among conditioned dharmas, volition is the most excellent in its ability to create.
Volition is only included in this formation aggregate.
Therefore, this formation aggregate alone is named formation.
Question: Among the mental factors such as the universal mental factors,
why are feeling and conceptualization established separately as aggregates,
while the other mental factors are not established separately?

If a dharma is capable of independently establishing an aggregate, then it is established as an aggregate.
If it is not capable of independently establishing an aggregate, then it is established together as an aggregate. Therefore, one should not question it.
Furthermore,
the World-Honored One wishes to adorn the meaning with different characteristics and different texts.
Therefore, he speaks like this.

That is to say, if the Buddha adorns the meaning with different characteristics and different texts, then those who receive the teaching will joyfully accept and uphold it without giving rise to weariness.
Furthermore, the World-Honored One wishes to manifest two doors, two summaries, two steps, two ladders, two torches, two lights, two shadows, and therefore speaks like this.
That is to say, just as feeling and conceptualization are established separately as aggregates,
the other mental factors should also be established separately.
Just as the other mental factors are combined and established as the aggregate of mental activities,ğŸ”½...
Feeling and conceptualization should also be combined and established as aggregates.
In this way, there should be innumerable aggregates.
Or there should be only three, because there are two doors and two shadows.
There are five aggregates, neither less nor more.
Furthermore, the World-Honored One wishes to reveal the essentials of the two doors of the Dharma.
Therefore, feeling and conceptualization are separately established as aggregates.
That is to say, among the mental factors, some have the nature of faculties and some do not.
If it is said that feeling is separately established as an aggregate, one should understand that the faculties and mental factors have already been discussed.
If it is said that conceptualization is separately established as an aggregate, one should understand that the non-faculties and mental factors have already been discussed.
Just as there are those with the nature of faculties and those without the nature of faculties,ğŸ”½there are those with the nature of illumination and those without the nature of illumination,
those with the nature of direct perception and those without the nature of direct perception,
those with the nature of delight in contemplation and those without the nature of delight in contemplation,
those with the nature of subtlety and those without the nature of subtlety,ğŸ”½those with the nature of supremacy and those without the nature of supremacy,
those with the nature of power and those without the nature of power,
and those with the nature of predominance and those without the nature of predominance should be understood in the same way.
Furthermore, the two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization are separately established as aggregates because they manifest in two realms.
That is to say, the aggregate of feeling is manifested in the form realm.
Because feeling such as joy and pleasure increases in the form realm.
The aggregate of conception is manifested in the formless realm, because conceptions such as space and consciousness increase in the formless realm.
Furthermore, because of two dharmas,
yogis become weary in the two realms, and therefore the aggregates are separately established.
That is to say, because of the power of feeling, yogis become weary in the form realm.
Because of the power of conception, yogis become weary in the formless realm.
Furthermore, sentient beings
are attached to pleasurable feelings and grasp inverted conceptions,
revolving in the cycle of birth and death and experiencing various intense sufferings.
In order to make them understand these two faults, the aggregates are separately established.
Furthermore, the two dharmas of feeling and conception give rise to the two roots of dispute.
Because they surpass other dharmas, they are separately established as aggregates.
That is to say, feeling can give rise to the root of dispute of craving,
and conception can give rise to the root of dispute of views.
Just as they can give rise to the two roots of dispute,
The two kinds of defilement, the two extremes, the two kinds of arrows, the two kinds of idle discourse, and the two kinds of â€œmineâ€ that are aroused are also to be understood in the same way.
Also, the two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization are established separately as stations of consciousness and therefore are established as separate aggregates.
The other mental activities are established as a single station of consciousness and therefore are established as a single aggregate.

Also, yogins and meditators detest feeling and conceptualization and enter the samÄdhi of cessation. Therefore they are established as separate aggregates. Having known this, he becomes disgusted with the two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization
and does not allow them to be born and attains the samÄdhi of cessation.
For these various reasons,
feeling and conceptualization are established as separate aggregates.
Why are the unconditioned not established as aggregates?
The answer is: because they do not have the characteristics of aggregates, they are not established as aggregates.
That is to say, aggregates have the characteristic of being a collection.
Because the unconditioned do not have this characteristic, they are not established as aggregates.
Moreover, the unconditioned is the ultimate cessation of the aggregates, so it is not established as an aggregate.
Just as the ultimate cessation of a pot or a garment is not a pot or a garment.
Moreover, conditioned dharmas are associated with arising and ceasing.
Having causes and conditions, they can obtain the characteristics of conditioned dharmas and be established as aggregates.
Unconditioned dharmas are not associated with arising and ceasing.
Because they do not have causes and conditions, they cannot obtain the characteristics of conditioned dharmas, and therefore are not established as aggregates.
Moreover, conditioned dharmas belong to causes and conditions, and the combination of causes and conditions can be established as aggregates.
Unconditioned dharmas are contrary to this, so they are not established as aggregates.
Moreover, conditioned dharmas are produced by birth.
They are weakened by old age.
They are destroyed by impermanence.
They can be established as aggregates.
Unconditioned dharmas are contrary to this, so they are not established as aggregates.
Furthermore, conditioned dharmas flow through the world.
They take effects and give effects, having various functions.
They can be established as aggregates because they can cognize objects.
Unconditioned dharmas are contrary to this, so they are not established as aggregates.
Furthermore, conditioned dharmas fall into the three time periods.
They are associated with suffering and have a beginning and end.
They can be established as aggregates because they have lower, middle, and upper levels.
Unconditioned dharmas are contrary to this, so they are not established as aggregates.
Furthermore, unconditioned dharmas do not have the characteristics of the five aggregates.
They cannot be established within these five aggregates.
They also cannot be established as a sixth aggregate.
Because they do not have the characteristics of the aggregates such as aggregation, etc.
Furthermore, the aggregates have the characteristic of being produced.
Unconditioned dharmas do not have the characteristic of being produced, so they are not established as aggregates.
Furthermore, the aggregates arise from others.
Because unconditioned dharmas do not arise from others, they are not established as aggregates.
For these and other various reasons, the unconditioned is not an aggregate.
As a sutra says:
There are five kinds of meritorious aggregates.
Namely, the aggregate of morality, the aggregate of concentration, the aggregate of wisdom, the aggregate of liberation, and the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of liberation.

How can it be said there are five?
Answer: Because those aggregates of morality, etc., are all included in these five, form, etc., the aggregates are only five.
